title: â€˜Weâ€™re related!â€™ Benjiâ€™s bizarre Bronco discovery
text:
Benji Marshall reveals he and fellow Brisbane Broncos star Jordan Kahu are related February 13, 2017 5:05pm @glover_benny Source: FOX SPORTS HE may have split his lip and strained his calf at the Auckland Nines but Benji Marshall isnâ€™t letting that bumpy introduction to the Broncos take the shine off what he describes as a dream pre-season at his new club. 
The former golden boot winner is comfortable with his place low down on the pecking order in Brisbane, admitting he wonâ€™t be upset if he spends the majority of 2017 playing reserve grade football for Redcliffe. 
Itâ€™s a different Marshall to the uber competitor weâ€™ve watched dominate for well over a decade, with the 31-year-old adamant a change of scenery has been the best thing for him. 
Itâ€™s even brought him closer to a relative he only discovered as an adult â€” a distant cousin who now stands between the former golden boot winner and a shot at a starting centre berth. 
The relative in question? Jordan Kahu. 
â€œWeâ€™re related!â€ Marshall excitedly reveals to foxsports.com.au when Kahuâ€™s name is raised. 
â€œI think it might be his grandmother and my grandfather are brother and sister. I donâ€™t know what it is but I know weâ€™re related.â€ 
If Marshall has got the connection right it would make he and Kahu second cousins, further explaining why the 26-year-old Kiwis star has been so eager to share his excitement at being on the same field as his new teammate. Benji Marshall runs the ball at Broncos training. Source: News Corp Australia 
â€œHis brother Jared used to play 20s for the Broncos back in the day and I remember playing up in Brisbane and Jared came up to me and said â€˜weâ€™re relatedâ€™,â€ Marshall recalls. 
â€œAnd then I asked my family and they said, â€˜yeah, yeah, weâ€™re related to themâ€™. 
â€œI canâ€™t believe it mate, you see a guy like Jordan, we played together the other day at the Nines and heâ€™s tweeting: â€˜Oh my god, I got to play at the Nines with Benji Marshallâ€™, which is like, â€˜who gives a s***, reallyâ€™. I just played alongside Benji Marshall ğŸ˜± â€” jordan kahu (@JordanKahu) February 4, 2017 
â€œBut itâ€™s very humbling to see that.â€ 
Humbling and potentially awkward, with left centre being one position identified as a good fit for the veteran recruit. 
Kahu has also put his hand up for the role vacated by the retirement of Jack Reed and has firmed as the favourite to fill it after an outstanding Auckland Nines campaign. 
â€œI think the thing for Jordy is heâ€™s really come on in leaps and bounds in his leadership and becoming a bit more of a senior player,â€ Marshall said. 
â€œObviously playing for New Zealandâ€™s helped him but not only that, if heâ€™s fit heâ€™ll be our first choice goalkicker so thereâ€™s no danger of him missing out on a spot. 
â€œIf heâ€™s fit heâ€™ll be playing first grade, Iâ€™ll be the one playing Q Cup and that doesnâ€™t bother me.â€ 
Marshall has trained at centre, as a back up in the halves and even spent some time at hooker since arriving in Brisbane. Jordan Kahu is a distant cousin of Benji Marshall, as well as a teammate. Source: News Corp Australia 
It points to a bench utility role that has been adequately filled by young gun Kodi Nikorima over the past two seasons. 
Marshall says heâ€™s ready for that kind of reduced role and is revelling away from the spotlight that comes with a playmaking role at NRL level. 
â€œPlaying halfback at the Dragons obviously thereâ€™s going to be a lot of pressure around that and the results, if you win or lose you get the credit or the blame,â€ Marshall said. 
â€œI guess when you go to a team like the Broncos where Iâ€™m not in that position anymore the pressureâ€™s not so much on me to have to do those things. 
â€œIâ€™ve just been able to relax and just cruise. Thereâ€™s no pressure. 
â€œWayne told me that thereâ€™s no need for me to be the man there because weâ€™ve got 10 players there already who are already on top of the game. 
â€œThatâ€™s helped me to relax and not feel like thereâ€™s any pressure on me to have to do anything, I can just enjoy myself, and to be honest Iâ€™m really enjoying it and Iâ€™m happy.â€
